chapter.title: Frequently Asked Questions
chapter.para: The following is a list of frequently asked questions regarding the publican toolchain:

question.para: How do I add another language to my book?

answer.para: Append the language to OTHER_LANGS in the Makefile. Run the make update-po-language command. For example, make update-po-ja-JP creates the language directory and language specific po files.

question.para: What if I only use the country code? For example, OTHER_LANGS = en de fr?
How do I update all po files?
Where can I get a complete list of make targets?
Where can I get a complete list of parameters that can be set in the Makefile?
Where are the publican common files located?

answer.para: By default they are in the /usr/share/publican directory.

question.para: Can I use the OASIS DocBook DTD for XML completion in editors such as Kate?

answer.para: Yes. The OASIS DocBook DTD is included in the publican package, and is located here: /usr/share/publican/xsl/docbook.dtd.xml

question.para: I have extensive code samples for my book, how can I include them without having to xml escape everything?

answer.para: The best way to do this is to create a directory named extras in your source language directory and use an xi:include to pull in the code file.

listitem.para:
Create the extras directory
mkdir en-US/extras

Copy the code file to the extras directory
cp ~/samples/foo.c en-US/extras/.

xi:iclude the sample file in your xml file
<programlisting> <xi:include parse="text" href="extras/foo.c" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" /> </programlisting>
You can now edit en-US/extras/foo.c in your favorite editor without having to be concerned about how it will affect the XML.

question.para: Is it possible to include arbitrary files in tar and rpm files?

answer.para: Yes. If you make a directory named files in your source language directory it will be included in any tar or srpm files created by publican.

warning.title: Warning
warning.para: The files directory will not be available during the validation process so you can not xi:include or otherwise embed any files in this directory in your XML.
